agency_impact: The Board of Pharmacy now offers unqualified support for the measure, with its Executive Officer stating, "The Board voted unanimously to support this measure (HB72_SD1_TESTIMONY_CPN_03-27-25_)." The Board also reports it "recently formed a permitted interaction group to look at the best methods to regulate pharmacy technicians for quality and general assurance (HB72_SD1_TESTIMONY_CPN_03-27-25_)." The Board agreed that "a registration for all technicians may be a prudent initial step regarding the regulation of pharmacy technicians (HB72_SD1_TESTIMONY_CPN_03-27-25_)."
economic_impact: Testimony now characterizes the initiative as coming at a "reasonable cost" and representing "a prudent investment in ensuring the safety, efficiency, and adaptability of our pharmacy workforce (HB72_SD1_TESTIMONY_CPN_03-27-25_)." Walgreens supports the measure as it "exempts this measure from the requirements of a sunrise analysis due to the exigent need for technician regulation (HB72_SD1_TESTIMONY_CPN_03-27-25_)." The Committee on Commerce and Consumer Protection "received testimony in support of this measure from the University of Hawaiʻi System, Board of Pharmacy, Walgreen Co., and nine individuals (HB72_SD1_SSCR1642_)."
policy_impact: The policy scope has been further clarified to include adopting "a definition of 'auxiliary personnel' for personnel such as cashiers whose responsibilities are purely clerical in nature" and clarifying "the specific duties of a pharmacy technician" and "a pharmacist’s supervision of a technician (HB72_SD1_TESTIMONY_CPN_03-27-25_)." This measure also "builds upon Act 104 that allows, in part, pharmacists, pharmacy technicians and pharmacy interns the ability to administer immunizations and vaccinations (HB72_SD1_TESTIMONY_CPN_03-27-25_)." Testimony notes that this measure "will lay the foundation for pharmacy technicians in Hawai‘i to expand their scope of practice in the future (HB72_SD1_TESTIMONY_CPN_03-27-25_)."
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: This fiscal note is updated based on new testimony before the Senate Committee on Commerce and Consumer Protection. The Board of Pharmacy has shifted its position to unqualified support, as it "voted unanimously to support this measure (HB72_SD1_TESTIMONY_CPN_03-27-25_)" without the previously mentioned requests for amendments. New policy details clarify that the bill defines "auxiliary personnel," clarifies technician duties, and is exempt from a sunrise analysis (HB72_SD1_TESTIMONY_CPN_03-27-25_). The measure now explicitly "builds upon Act 104" regarding immunizations, and the breadth of support has been specified, with the Committee receiving testimony from the "University of Hawaiʻi System, Board of Pharmacy, Walgreen Co., and nine individuals (HB72_SD1_SSCR1642_)." No new financial figures were introduced, though testimony affirms the initiative "comes at a reasonable cost (HB72_SD1_TESTIMONY_CPN_03-27-25_)."
